div.head:
APPENDIX 6:
Royal Entry of Katherine of Aragon, November 1501

div.p: This appendix provides examples, from manuscript records of the royal entry of Katherine of Aragon in November 150I (see Appendix I), of the types of entry records not normally transcribed for The Records but included as references either in explanatory notes to the transcribed records or within diamond brackets below the relevant dated listings in Appendix 1. Such records appear in the main body of the collection only when interwoven in the manuscripts with records of theatrical activity or music. Largely such excluded records involve one or more of riders to meet the entrant at his/her approach to the city, the rails behind which companies stood along the entry route, the standings (or platforms, including rails) upon which they stood, the breaking and subsequent repairing of the pavement where the standings rails were placed, costs of food and drink, sand or gravel laid down on London Bridge and in the streets (to cushion the horses hooves and prevent them from sliding), gifts, detail of liveries worn, debts for riding costs, fines of those absenting themselves from riding (attendance on these occasions being normally compulsory for company members), and other such non- musical, non theatrical elements of these occasions. (For the cushioning of horses' hooves, see Leland,Collectanea, vol 4, p 10.) Such elements were standard for major entries, and many of them also for more routine entries not usually involving theatrical and for which there are normally no records of music (although trumpets, at least, must almost nvariably have been used). Also, although approvals of assessments to cover costs at royal entries have been included within The Records, detailed collection arrangements and arrears, such as those transcribed below from Repertory I, are normally merely cited in endnotes or in Appendix 1 listings.

Katherine of Aragon and Prince Arthur (heir to the throne of England) had been married to one another by proxy in May 1499, but Katherine's arrival in England had been delayed until late 1501, when finally she arrived at Plymouth on 2 Qctober. A lengthy progress to London then took place, with the royal entry through the city (from Lambeth) on 12 November and the wedding at St Paul's on 14 November. On 16 November the court moved by water from the city to Westminster, for celebrations there with tournaments, banquets, and the like. On 26 November a civic escort accompanied the court up the river from Westminster to Mortlake (adiacent to Richmond). (See the main records transcribed under 1499-1500, 1500-1, and 1501-2:, also Appendix I under 1501-2 (12, 14, 16, and 26 November) and the ODNB.) The events preceding and following 12 November were
not part of the royal entry through the city, but company non-musical, non-theatrical records of them have nevertheless been included below because, relating to the same period pf celebration, they extend the range of examples of records not typically included within The Records.

Several of the records require the provision here of additional information. For an explana- tion of the last line of the items from Repertory I, see the related Mercers Company's record below. The manuscript heading (not transcribed) for the payments from f 32v of the Bakers' Company's accounts states that this account is for two years, 15 and 16 Henry VII (that is, 22 August 1499 to 2I August 1501)' since the company's accounting year generally runs from one 23 November to the next, and the record concerns the 12 November royal entry, the heading almost certainly indicates 23 November 1499-23 November 1501. In the first Brewers' Company record, a list of sixty-four names, at 6d each, precedes the tota transcribed. The third Brewers' record refers to jousts, records of tournaments or joustings which do not mention either music or theatrical elements such as role-playing are by standard REED policy excluded from The Records, and in any case these specific [ousts are at Westminster. The Drapers' Company's record of barge hire to Westminster with the king is internally dated 20 November; after the wedding on 14 October the court, as noted above, travelled by water to Westminster on 16 November (see Appendix 1), so either the 20th is a payment (not event) date or (much less likely) there was another occasion on the 20th requiring an escort. A Drapers' record of payment concerning the water escort to Mortlake is included in The Records because referring to music, and is also dated later than the date, according to other sources, of the occasion itself.

The reference to Southampton in the Grocers; Company's payments transcribed is related to Katherine of Aragons' arrival on 2 October at nearby Plymouth; she was supposd to have landed at Southampton (see Kipling, Recyt, p 115). In the items from the Skinners' Company's accounts, the reference in the second-to-last payment to all the times includes not only the occasions mentioned in the payments transcribed but also the occasions of the hire of barges to Westminster for the sheriff's presentation in September 1501 and for the mayor's oath- taking in October 1501 (both occasions with transcribed records in the main body of this collection). The transcribed record from f 60 of the Wiresellers' Company's accounts is followed in the manuscript by a list of names and sums, but no total is provided, and not all of the individuals listed may be providing money for this particular purpose; after the first eight names come three without a sum (one of which is deleted), and of five further names, one is paying for two or three years, one for two years past, one in part payment of a fine, and one for this year.

The Goldsmiths' Company was no doubt heavily involved in the receiving of Katherine of Aragon, since goldsmith John Shaa was mayor of London in November 1501. A manuscript record (Goldsmith's Hall: MS 1520, p 385) of fines for two individuals absent when the company 'ffetched the prynce & pryncesse frome Grenewiche' does not seem, however, to be related to the entry, and the record has therefore not been included below. No editorial headings have been supplied for the records other than those in the manu- scripts themselves. The records have been ordered as in any one year of The Records.
For all document descriptions, except for the Wiresellers' Wardens' Account below, see The Documents.

div.head: Wiresellers' Wardens' Accounts
div.p: The accounting year runs most often from one November to the November two years later, for the Pinners, and apparently August/September to August/September in either two-year or three-year spans, for the Wiresellers. Further detail on the contents of the manuscript is provided in the BL Catalogue of Additions, vol 8: 1846-1847 (1864), 197-8.

¶Eodem die Eodem die: 2 December datus est dies cuilibet Aldermanno ad inportanda arreragis enariorum assessorum super wardas suas erga aduentum domine katerine filie filie: e correctect over j Regis e lspanie die louis proximo sequenti s & hoc sub pena inprisonamenti
Memorandum Clerici Maioris & vicecomitum erunt contributoriy Ad omnia onera &c.
Adnullatum postea Ad Curiam tempore Rest Maioris

Item Consideratum est quod clerici curie Maioris et clerici computatoriorum computatoriorum: for computato de nec non seruientes et valecti Maioris et vicecomtum de cetero erunt contributorijs ad omnia onera assessa sicut alij ciues secundum facultates suas se ita tamen quod de vigilijs & ceteris officijs viz. constahularijs et similes similes: for similibus penitus exonerabuntu ffinis xxti li. assessus super s Misteram Mercerorum

row.cell: Item payd for brekyng of the pament In cornell when ye lady katerine come to london
viij d.
ltem payd to Richert smythe carpynter for makyng of ye Raylles for ye standyng
xiij s. iij d.
Item payd for di. a C of vj dj. nayll for ye Rayll
vj d. ob.
Item payd for caryge of the same Rayll
j d
Item payd for a lode of gravell
iiij d. iiij d.: probable reading; sum not clear
Item payd for stys for ye pament
vj d.
ltem payd for the yng of the same pament
ij s.

ltem for the takyng vp of the pament where your standding was the tyme the princes came oute of spayne in to london vj d. ltem paid to thomas A wode Carpenter. for xv. yearrd of lengithe Closid be four & be hynd be Cavse of pres of the peopill .xij. s. Summa
xij. s. vj d.
ltem for the pavyng & dreshing of the same pament Ageynne
iij. s. iiij d.

div.head: p [8] of 1501-2 account Rendered 21 February 1502/3)
div.ab: Mony Resse₻ea ffor Stondynge in cornell xxjj ss. [vj d.]

ltem the Seid Accommptauntes Chargeth them Selff with certayn mony by 3 them Ressaued of dyuers personez beyng in the leuerey of Blew toward the costes made And Raled in Cornell at commyng In of the lady princez kateryn kinges doughter of Spayn Maried to arthur prince of ynglon

row.cell: Item Paid ffor Makyng of A Raile for the hole Company of our crafte made by lohn Clerk Carpenter In cornell At Ressauyng of my lady princez kateryn secund doughtan doughtan: for doughter vnto kyng of Cspayn Maried vnto Arthur Prince Prrince: e corrected over another letter of Inglond he first son of kyng henry vijth vijth: v corrected over s or f
xliiij s. xj d.

div.head: p [17] of 1501-2 account (Costs of various dinners)

row.cell: ffirst costes made of A dener vnto the hole Company In th lyuerey beyng present with [the] Sir lohn Shaa knyght thei Maire In takyng his othe At westminster the Barons of th kynges escheker then kepyng ther court at that tyme In the synges Stondyng then at that tyme ordendyned and mad for the lustes at the Mariage of prince Arthur And Tatery secund doughter of kyng of Spayn
liiij s. vj d.
Item paid for xxiiijti yardes of Rayle for the Crafte to stand in At the Comyng of the prynses of spayne
xvj s. viij d.
Item paid for pavyng of the holys there the Rayle stode
ij s. iiij d.

xxx s.
ltem for drinking money to the Carpenters at diuers tymes
viij d.
ltem for Bargehire to Westmimnster with the king the xxti day of Nouembre
xiij s. iiij d.
Item paid for the standyng of our Compeigny]g] and pavyng of the ground
xxj s. vij d.

iij li. iiij s. viij d.

v li. xj s. iiij d.

div.head: f 87(15 July 1501- 15 July 1503) (Payments)
div.ab: Whan The Prynses was Recei₻ea yn to london

row.cell: ffyrste payde to A Carpynter for to make A frame for The felyschype to stande yn to se her Summa
x s. vj d.
Item payde to iiij laborers for A daye to set yt wpe
xx d.
Item payde for Caryinge of the tymber And Borde
viij d.
Item payde for naylynge of the Same
vij d. ob
Item payde for brede and Ale Candylle & for scharpyn, of þe ssryn
viij d.
Item payde for pavynge a gen of the Strete
ij s. iiij d.

div.ab: Summa xvj s. v d. ob./

div.head: Mercers' Acts of Court MH: Acts of Court 1
f 122v (17 December)
div.p:
[symbol]Where as diuers persones of oure lyuerey com not to the barge when the kynges good grace went from Westmimster to Mortelake/ and also som that come late/ where thorough grete displeasure was taken by my lorde Mayre & my Maisters thaldermen In so myche they in a Courte holden at the
yelde hall mercyde oure felishipp for the said trespas at vj li. xiij s. iiij d. for the repayment of the same it is agreed that it shalbe levied uppon suche persones as were warned and made defaute &c

row.cell: Item paid for the hyre of a Bote of vj owers to accompany ane to attende vpon the prynces from london to Westmynster
vij s. vj d.
Item rewardyd the Botemene and for brede and Drynk spen vpon theym and our company
xviij d.
Item for the hyre of a grete Bote to Wayte vpon the prynces rom Westmynster to Rychemond
xv s. vj d.
Item rewardyd the Botemen
xviij d.
Item paid for Rysshes for the said Barges and Botys by all the said tymes
xij d.
Item paid for our Scaffold stondyng in Chepesyde ayenst the commyng yn of the prynces to london
xl s.

div.head: f 58v (1501-4)
div.ab: Item payd to thomas A wod Carpynter ffor makyng off owr skaffowlld A yen the prynces cam in v s. j d. and to the laboras ffor makyng off the hollys ffor the tymbyr and ffor the stopyng A yen ij s. ij d.
[tem payd att ij tymes [fo] to the karter ffor bryngyng owr [(.)ey] stuff ffron Ihon Allssopp one tyme iiij d. the second tyme iij d

Item payd ffor the hangyng up of owr clothys And bestoyng
off owr stuff ...d.

div.head: f 60
div.ab: Receued off the brether to the makyng off the skaffolld in Cornell ayen the prynsses cam.
div.note: followed by a list of 8 contributions totalling 11s 4d
